QAPair.Question: What is (are) McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Type V (five) glycogen storage disease (GSD V) is a rare inherited condition in which the body is not able to break down glycogen. Glycogen is an important source of energy that is stored in all tissues, especially in the muscles and liver. GSD V is also called McArdle disease.

QAPair.Question: What causes McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: GSD V is caused by a flaw in the gene that makes an enzyme called muscle glycogen phosphorylase. As a result, the body cannot break down glycogen in the muscles. GSD V is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder. This means to have the disorder, you must receive a copy of the nonworking gene from both parents. A person who receives a nonworking gene from only one parent usually does not develop this syndrome. A family history of GSD V increases the risk.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms commonly start during early childhood. But, it may be difficult to separate these symptoms from those of normal childhood. Diagnosis may not occur until a person is over 20 or 30 years old. Burgundy-colored urine (myoglobinuria), Fatigue, Exercise intolerance, poor stamina, Muscle cramps, Muscle pain , Muscle stiffness, Muscle weakness,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: The following tests may be performed: Electromyography (EMG) , Genetic testing , Lactic acid in blood , MRI , Muscle biopsy , Myoglobin in urine , Plasma ammonia, Serum creatine kinase ,

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: There is no specific treatment. The health care provider may suggest the following to stay active and healthy and prevent symptoms: Be aware of your physical limitations., Before exercising, warm up gently., Avoid exercising too hard or too long., Eat enough protein., Ask your provider if it's a good idea to eat some sugar before exercising. This may help prevent muscle symptoms. If you need to have surgery, ask your provider if it's OK for you to have general anesthesia.

QAPair.Question: Where to find support for people with McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: More information and support for people with type V glycogen storage condition and their families can be found at: Association for Glycogen Storage Disease -- www.agsdus.org , National Organization for Rare Disease Disorders -- rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/6528/glycogen-storage-disease-type-5 ,

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: People with GSD V can live a normal life by managing their diet and physical activity.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Exercise may produce muscle pain, or even a breakdown of skeletal muscle ( rhabdomyolysis ). This condition is associated with burgundy-colored urine and a risk for kidney failure if it is severe.

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for McArdle syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your provider if you have repeated episodes of sore or cramped muscles after exercise, especially if you also have burgundy or pink urine. Consider genetic counseling if you have a family history of GSD V.
